stem: The nurse is administering ear drops to a 2-year-old child. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Instruct the child (or parent) to remain in the side-lying position for 2-3 minutes.
Pull the pinna down and back.
Gently massage the tragus of the ear.
Instill the prescribed number of drops along the side of the ear canal.
Position the child side-lying with the affected ear facing up.

rationale.correct: Proper ear drop technique depends on the patient's age. (1) Positioning ensures the drop stays in. (2) For children under 3, the Eustachian tube is horizontal; pulling DOWN and BACK straightens it. (3) Side instillation prevents air bubbles. (4) Massaging the tragus helps the drop move down the canal. (5) Absorption time.
rationale.incorrect: Pulling the pinna 'up and back' for a child under 3 is incorrect and will not straighten the canal.
clinicalPearls: Warm the ear drops in the palm of the hand before administration. Small children can experience vertigo or nausea if cold drops are instilled into the ear.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Down and Back' for small children (they are short/down). 'Up and Back' for adults (they are tall/up).

reviewUnits.heading: Administration of Otic Medications
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for pain and drainage. If both ears require drops, wait 5 minutes between sides.
